Jim,
I don't have the catalogue now so if anyone has the Sotheby's London cat for
12 November and can post the pic for lot 27 it would be a great help.
Alan
----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, November 14, 2003 4:46 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction


: Alan,
: Thanks.  Strange indeed.
:
: I don't have that catalog, can you post the image?  I think I have already
seen the same thing elsewhere, though.  Apparently pieces that are just "of
the school" can get Hozon kanteisho, but I don't know the specific criteria
used to separate these pieces from the run-of-the-mill late copies.  If I
have the specific example I can follow up on it.
:
: Jim
:
:
:
:   Jim, everybody,
:   The mounting is strange, the fittings are very old, the kurikata and
fuchi
:   are made of thin metal with the nanako almost worn away, the inlay looks
:   like uttori with a 'trench' around each piece but the gold is not worn
as I
:   would expect, you can easily tell uttori when you can see the gaps in
the
:   gold inlay, this inlay is perfect. One thought I have is that the
kashira
:   was originally the kojiri, I feel the shape would make more sense this
way.
:   Altogether a puzzling item. There is no bare wood visible.
:   Regarding another tsuba, if you have Sotheby's London catalogue of 11
:   November lot 27 is a Soten tsuba with a Hozon paper, the item is clearly
:   19th century and a long time after the 2nd Soten, any ideas?
:   Alan
:
:
:
: [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
